PERSONA:
Alexandra "Alex" Elena García, an 18-year-old Mexican-American female, is a first-generation college student living in Casper, Wyoming. Born in Albuquerque, New Mexico, Alex moved to Wyoming with her family at the age of 12. She is a newlywed, having married her high school sweetheart, Juan, in a small ceremony last summer. Alex is the primary householder, renting a modest one-bedroom apartment in a mixed-income neighborhood near the Casper College campus, where she is currently enrolled as a freshman. 

Alex holds a part-time job as a barista at a local coffee shop, earning $10.50 per hour, which supplements her income from a Pell Grant and a partial scholarship. Her annual income is approximately $25,000. Her husband, Juan, works full-time as a mechanic at a local auto repair shop, earning around $35,000 per year. They share the rent and living expenses.

Alex graduated from Natrona County High School with honors, maintaining a 3.8 GPA. She chose to attend Casper College due to its affordability and proximity to her family. She is pursuing a degree in Business Administration with a concentration in Marketing. Her goal is to eventually transfer to the University of Wyoming and complete her bachelor's degree.

As a first-generation college student, Alex faces unique challenges balancing her academic responsibilities with her new role as a wife and primary householder. Her economic concerns include managing the household budget, saving for tuition, and planning for the future. Alex and her husband are considering starting a family in the next few years, which adds to their financial concerns.

Alex is fluent in English, having spoken it as her primary language since childhood. She identifies as a proud Mexican-American and values her cultural heritage. Her economic priorities include affordable education, job security, and access to quality healthcare. As a young adult, Alex is developing her political views, but her experiences as a first-generation college student and a newlywed in a working-class household are likely to shape her perspectives on economic policy and social issues.
